history.content:
I would say it's not particularly important. Though if you are interested in computer graphics/visual computing, the signal processing in that class and EE120 will come in handy. Also, I think there's more to learn about linear algebra than was just in Math 54. Personally, I've been in 5 classes that started teaching Linear Algebra from scratch, and they've all provided very different intuitions and approaches to problem solving that have been useful. However, there is a reason it's not required for CS Majors, and you won't be significantly disadvantaged relative to students who do take it.

Edit: I think I should clarify a couple things about my answer here. I should have said that the material in 16B did not come up very often in later CS classes. However, I can't speak to how important having a basic understanding of that material is outside of the classes that I've taken, and I trust that if it's being made a requirement, that it is important. Personally, I took and enjoyed 16B and a couple of follow up classes.

TL;DR: I meant only to say that 16B material doesn't appear much in upper division CS classes, not that the material itself is unimportant beyond that.

I would say it's not particularly important. Though if you are interested in computer graphics/visual computing, the signal processing in that class and EE120 will come in handy. Also, I think there's more to learn about linear algebra than was just in Math 54. Personally, I've been in 5 classes that started teaching Linear Algebra from scratch, and they've all provided very different intuitions and approaches to problem solving that have been useful. However, there is a reason it's not required for CS Majors, and you won't be significantly disadvantaged relative to students who do take it.

children.subject: +1, I share all the above sentiments about 16B.

I don't agree with the student answer. I think that EE16B showed me what EE really is: so much more than just circuits/hardware. If you think you know that you don't like signal processing, control, etc etc then I guess maybe you won't like the class, but I think most CS majors have very little understanding of this non-circuits part of EE.

Also tbh the circuits part of 16B (phasors aka complex numbers are actually useful) was way more interesting than I thought it would be (more interesting than 16A which just had to lay foundations).

TL;DR perhaps not directly useful to your current path, BUT for me, was super interesting and opened me up to lots of cool topics (taking EE120 now).

history.content:
16B was added as a requirement for everyone precisely because it is important to know in the long run. Foundations needs to prepare students for a multi-decade career, and it is pretty clear that a general CS student better know something about control, signal processing, and learning. Even if you are not going to focus on it, you never know when you will interact with those ideas during your career. If autonomous vehicles and smart devices become a large part of the computing ecosystem (instead of just laptops, servers, and smartphones/tablets), then this is pretty important grounding. Similarly, the basic kinds of optimization-thinking that 16AB together develop is foundational. 

Of course, for students interested at all in machine learning, robotics, or circuit design, 16B needs to be taken as soon as possible since it sets the stage for later courses.
Its not a requirement for my year since i took 54 and 16a, and I’m not really interested in ML or hardware. Wondering if theres any other fields where 16b is a necessity/very helpful.
history.subject: How important is 16b for a cs major?
